text:
I’d say yes, there’s a massive lack of sensitivity to this and to UI and interaction design in general, but then that’s an extremely biased opinion I formed as part of a job to educate and help developers with this on a platform that cares about such things (and which has in fact been rewriting the whole stack from the ground up, down to and including the hardware).

If we have to take care of this ourselves is a separate question. I hope we don’t and platforms will take care of this for us. We “just” need to be aware and make sure that we adopt the new ways and APIs offered to take advantage of this.
Dscript is an attempt to take a simple alphabetic language and convert it into Chinese. A completely mad project, but amusing to be sure.
CodeCrumbs might be relevant to this discussion: <https://github.com/Bogdan-Lyashenko/codecrumbs/blob/master/docs/main-ui-3.png>
two things that caught my attention recently,
i ADORE this graphical workspace overview system in this gif, <https://mobile.twitter.com/round/status/1159528332377165824>

text: (hat tip to @round & his visual programming (althought not super applicable here honestly, this is a view of conventional programming))

This is interesting. Certainly a "weakness" of alphabetic scripts are their inefficient use of character-wise-space compared to logographic ones(see Japanese twitter vs. English twitter) so compensating for that by relaxing the linearity constraint at the word-level is a neat way to get around that.

From the description it's not super clear to me if this is a "serious" or a "fun" conlang tho(or maybe that's a false distinction!). The claims in uscript.pdf do seem a bit grandoise tho...

and master of editors Marijn Havebeke talking about programs as a series of immutable states comes very close to my aspirations & desires,
<https://mobile.twitter.com/MarijnJH/status/1191720489523318786>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/MarijnJH|@MarijnJH>: Are there any incremental computation systems that treat inputs not as mutable cells, but model the whole system as a persistent data structure, and updates create a new, structure-sharing instance?
attachments.text: Are there any incremental computation systems that treat inputs not as mutable cells, but model the whole system as a persistent data structure, and updates create a new, structure-sharing instance?

text:
hmm I haven't dug into it yet myself, but I ran across this idea called "differential dataflow" that seems to be using the right words. I think one of the contributors to this implementatiion was experimenting with extending it to a React-js like system for transparently generating DOM:

<https://github.com/TimelyDataflow/differential-dataflow>

Differential dataflow is an iterative, incremental, stream processor basically. The rust version of Eve was based on taking the main idea behind differential dataflow and specializing it for a datalog-ish semantics. It worked very well, though implementing it is extremely unintuitive.
It's really great work. Frank McSherry (the guy who started it) is one of my absolute favorite people in the space. He's wonderfully irreverent :slightly_smiling_face:
lovely chit chat from dave geddes @geddski on building a higher level component to update the state machines of his web games, <https://mobile.twitter.com/geddski/status/1192193857946931200>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/geddski|@geddski>: state machines can help you explicitly craft the state/flow. Here’s the <LevelSwitcher /> state machine: <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EIuF_oWU0AIabpp.jpg>
